(8 comments)

yeah, I agree. recently I too noticed issue.
Modify gateway should be allowed.
Done
let me know if you need any help in testing this patch
yes, any help you can give would be appreciated.
Done

I have verified this patch,
Modifying gateway with single IP address works.
I see error while adding new ip with different gateway on the same interfaces
I'm getting 401 unauthorised and loosing connection.

curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token:${bmc_token}" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X PATCH -D patch.txt -d '{"IPv4StaticAddresses":[{},{"Address":"10.9.9.95","SubnetMask": "255.255.255.0","Gateway":"10.9.9.1"}]}' https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth0

If you're sending [{}.... 

you must've already loaded a static IP?  Can you give the full set of commands you ran from a factory reset BMC?

I'm really surprised to see 401..... There's only a few calls to that and none of them in the networking code.  If you get me a set of curl commands to reproduce I can try them.

1. Configured one static IP 
2. Add 2nd IP with different gateway on same interface, looks like bmcweb crashed.
I think I found the issue.  Can you retest with the latest?

Tested the scenarios:
1. Modifying Gateway - Worked

2. On adding new IP with same gateway getting 400 bad request but IP is getting added with old gateway
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X PATCH -D patch.txt -d '{"IPv4StaticAddresses":[{},{"Address": "9.3.29.125","SubnetMask": "255.255.255.0","Gateway":"9.3.29.1"}]}' https://$bmc/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth0

3. On adding new IP with different gateway getting 400 bad request but IP is getting added with old gateway
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token:${bmc_token}" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X PATCH -D patch.txt -d '{"IPv4StaticAddresses":[{},{"Address":"10.9.9.95","SubnetMask": "255.255.255.0","Gateway":"10.9.9.1"}]}' https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth0

4. On adding two IP addresses and deleting one IP seeing that Gateway is getting deleted.
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token" -H "Content-Type: application/json"  -X PATCH -D patch.txt -d '{"IPv4StaticAddresses":[null]}' https://$bmc/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth0

I am trying the same on my own machine ATM.
PATCH :url/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth1
Content-Type: application/json
{
     "IPv4StaticAddresses": [
     {
             "Address": "192.168.20.11",
             "SubnetMask": "255.255.255.0",
             "Gateway": "192.168.20.1"
     }
     ]
}

I can send this repeatedly, and it will accept it.
I can take away the address, and subnetmask, and it still works as expected.

Take this with a grain of salt, however.
Intel is substantially behind the most recent bmcweb state.
SHA: 6d0b80be1b79122de60ade0b80460510696954e0
This is over 130 commits behind the origin.
This particular PATCH command is part of a series I used to test the Gateway handling in the first place. I was surprised when this commit came in, as I was certain I had confirmed the correct behavior.

I need to talk with you more about it, but I wanted to start from something more than "i'm seeing a bug".

I don't really care whether or not this merges, but so far as I can test, we're broken.

I would've expected that:

"IPv4StaticAddresses": [
{
"Gateway": "192.168.20.1"
}

Would return a conflict if you tested on master, but I haven't had a change to dig super deep on this yet.  I just wanted to post something as a starting point to see if others were seeing the same conflict.
I was just going to see about trying to bisect this. The problem is we have so many patches. There are build artifacts elsewhere that depend on them. I'm not sure if I can be successful.
I appreciate the help, and honestly if the answer is that this patch is wrong and needs to die in a fire, that's fine.

I've performed a devtool checkout of bmcweb, and switched to SHA d109e2b60f7bb367dc8115475c6cb86bca6e1914 Refactor: move registries functions to their file

I am unable to duplicate the issue as stated.
My process (all via Redfish):
Disable DHCPv4 on eth1
Assign a single static IPv4 address, netmask, gateway. (x.x.x.11)
Issue the same request
Issue a request with only the Gateway in the PATCH
Issue a request to add two IPv4 addresses
   - The PATCH has the original assignment  (x.x.x.11)
   - The PATCH adds a second assignment (x.x.x.30)
Delete one static IPv4
Run the DELETE action a second time, clearing all static IPv4
Re-enable DHCPv4

All requests complete with a "204 No Content" response code.

There's something different in how we're activating the code, and I'd like to understand the variance. IMO it shouldn't matter what the NIC happens to be, NCSI vs USB.

> Disable DHCPv4 on eth1

This is probably the difference.  I leave DHCP enabled, so this hits different paths.

> Which is in error?
> phosphor-network explicitly blocks adding a gateway when dhcpv4 is active.

Ah, maybe this is the root of all my problems in this code.

>             if (!dhcp4())
>             {
>                 auto gateway4 = EthernetInterfaceIntf::defaultGateway();
>                 if (!gateway4.empty())
> So your https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/+/75860 commit is explicitly bypassing that check.
> 
> What is the correct behavior in this instance?
> While systemd doesn't block DHCPv4 and static V4 simultaneously, it is counter to the dominant paradigm.

I'm not really sure what that means.  I would expect that static ip addresses are orthogonal to dhcp addresses (in redfish they're different parameters).

Redfish has EthernetInterface.UseGateway that's means to be the selector for "Should you use the DHCP gateway, or the static gateways".

It would've been really nice if they just had a default gateway prop, or a gateway metrics list, but I guess that's not really how that works.

> IMO, if DHCPv4 is active, any PATCH of the StaticIPV4Addresses is violating common practice, and by extension needs to be blocked.

being able to support this makes testing considerably easier, because you can leave the dhcp in place, and just test the static addresses in isolation.  Maybe it's not common, but I could see the use case.

> I tested the change creating two static IPv4 addresses on the same NIC. Again, systemd doesn't prevent this. At the same time I'm not sure what value doing this has for something like a BMC.

Two static addresses definitely has value for non trivial deployments.

I reworked the patch heavily, and added unit tests to the portions we could so we can keep this stuff working.  If you could review it for overall thought process (ie breaking up the "parse in all the actions" and "perform all the actions") I'd appreciate it.
talked with jonathan on discord.  He's ok with this patch.
This is the bug.  We iterate twice.
Here are some of my observations.
Thank you for the review.

Change these instances to 
thisAddress.existingDbusId.empty()
?
If this entry doesn't have a value then the test on line 1520 failed.
Changed it.
Acknowledged
This sequence looks like it could benefit from a helper function for addr,subnet,gw.

I would, but each one is subtly different.

Address is required in all cases
Subnet mask needs to be parsed by ipv4VerifyIpAndGetBitcount and converted to a unint.
Gateway is optional

By the time we handle all those cases, we wouldn't have any less code.  I could break these out into sub-functions for each if we think that makes sense, but that also seems like more/messier code.

Happy to do whatever.
Leave it as is then.
ok

Is this the correct action?
Isn't it better to assume the remainder of the request was a series of "{}" entries?
Is there any guidance in the RF spec?

> Is this the correct action?

Given PATCH semantics, I believe this is correct.  The goal of PATCH is that if you send a value, that value is reproduced on a GET.  If we don't delete the remaining entries, PATCH no longer does what you asked for.

We could explicitly require that you have to explicitly set null or {} for every entry that exists, but this seemed more user friendly.

> Isn't it better to assume the remainder of the request was a series of "{}" entries?
> Is there any guidance in the RF spec?

I'm reading section 7.7 and I think this is right?

```. Array properties that use the fixed or variable length style remove those elements,
while array properties that use the rigid style replace removed elements with null elements```

I'm not positive this reading right and I've cut off a lot of context.  I think this behavior is what openbmc did before?
Acknowledged

Does this really work?
All it does is set the D-Bus entry and return, right?
Inspection of phosphor-network indicates that DHCPv4 assigned GW is going to remain in effect, and this assignment will be ignored.
Is it appropriate to report the fact the PATCH did not actually work?

> Does this really work?
> All it does is set the D-Bus entry and return, right?
> Inspection of phosphor-network indicates that DHCPv4 assigned GW is going to remain in effect, and this assignment will be ignored.

This works when done in tandem with my other patch that I linked in the commit message.

> Is it appropriate to report the fact the PATCH did not actually work?

I'm not sure I understand.
Let me test without that change present.

Testing without your phos-net change I would expect this BMCWeb code to report 200 or 204 when DHCPv4 is active. In spite of BMCWeb reporting "success", phos-net will not assign a Gateway value.
If phos-net doesn't apply the gateway requested, is BMCWeb reporting "success" desirable behavior?
Will updateIPv4Default error out if DHCPv4 is active? It doesn't appear phos-net returns an error, it just fails to write the gw into the config file.
I don't recall your philosophy wrt applying "policy" within BMCWeb.

> Testing without your phos-net change I would expect this BMCWeb code to report 200 or 204 when DHCPv4 is active. In spite of BMCWeb reporting "success", phos-net will not assign a Gateway value.

Just so I understand, is this the behavior we had before this patch, or do you think this is behavior is new in this patch?  I don't see any code in the existing handleIPv4StaticPatch method that's changing behavior dependent on whether DHCP is enabled.

> If phos-net doesn't apply the gateway requested, is BMCWeb reporting "success" desirable behavior?

Hard to say because technically I think our behavior is wrong to the standard anyway.  Long term what I suspect is that we really should be implementing "UseGateway" which lets you explicitly switch between DHCP and Static addresses for gateway.  If UseGateway == true, we should error out on setting the gateway.  If UseGateway = false, we shouldn't try to set the gateway at all, and just set dhcp.

> Will updateIPv4Default error out if DHCPv4 is active? It doesn't appear phos-net returns an error, it just fails to write the gw into the config file.
> I don't recall your philosophy wrt applying "policy" within BMCWeb.

If we have constraints that aren't specific to Redfish (IE, we can't set a gateway if DHCP is enabled), then they should be enforced in the backend, otherwise we're duplicating all behaviors in IPMI and Redfish.

If the constraint is redfish specific, fine to go in bmcweb.

I suspect phosphor-network should be returning an error if DHCP is enabled given its current implementation.

I thought about it more,

I think that phosphor-network should accept a string value of "DHCP" for default gateway, in which case it will set the default gateway to whatever DHCP provides, same as disabling DHCP.  bmcweb could then wire that to the "UseDHCP" setting in Redfish.

UseDHCP = True; DefaultGateway = "DHCP";
UseDHCP = False; DefaultGateway = first gateway in static ip list.
Talked with jonathan on discord.  He's ok with this patch, was just pointing out future issues to fix.
Is this comment correct? And the one ahead of the next TEST?

This comment is correct I think?  We're creating an object with all properties in both cases.  If there's something else better I should put here to make it more clear, let me know what you'd like to see.

IMO this isn't descriptive.
It would be nice to read a comment that describes the test behavior in English w/o having to grok the code.

This appears to actually:
Add two static IPv4 addresses with different gateway values.
Confirm the mismatched gateway values are rejected.
Added both those descriptions inline in code
Done
fails because 1.1.1.1 doesn't equal 192.168.1.1?
Fails because there already exists an entry with a different gateway.

See my suggested comment above.
The failure model did not jump out based on reading the code.
Done
More comments.....
Will add.  Thank you for the suggestion.
Done

Likewise....
Attempt to assign a gateway to a NIC that already has a static IPv4 address assigned.
Confirm the attempt to write an address containing a gateway value different from that already applied to the NIC is rejected.
Done
move to line 165 to match other test cases?
Moved.
Order of the parameters should be "address.prefixLength, address.address, address.gateway"
Yep.  This was fixed on another patch, then unfixed in a rebase.  Thank you for catching.
Fixed in latest patch.
